Social Welfare Maximization for Federated Learning with Network Effects

Xiang Li, Yuan Luo, Bing Luo, Jianwei Huangâ€ â€ footnotetext: Xiang Li is with Shenzhen Institute of Artificial Intelligence and Robotics for Society (AIRS), and the School of Science and Engineering (SSE), The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen (E-mail: xiangli2@link.cuhk.edu.cn). Bing Luo is with Data Science Research Center, Duke Kunshan University, Jiangsu (E-mail: bl291@duke.edu). Jianwei Huang is with SSE, AIRS, Shenzhen Key Laboratory of Crowd Intelligence Empowered Low-Carbon Energy Network, and CSIJRI Joint Research Centre on Smart Energy Storage, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Shenzhen, Guangdong, 518172, P.R. (2024)
Abstract.

A proper mechanism design can help federated learning (FL) to achieve good social welfare by coordinating self-interested clients through the learning process. However, existing mechanisms neglect the network effects of client participation, leading to suboptimal incentives and social welfare. This paper addresses this gap by exploring network effects in FL incentive mechanism design. We establish a theoretical model to analyze FL model performance and quantify the impact of network effects on heterogeneous client participation. Our analysis reveals the non-monotonic nature of FL network effects. To leverage such effects, we propose a model trading and sharing (MTS) framework that allows clients to obtain FL models through participation or purchase. To tackle heterogeneous clientsâ€™ strategic behaviors, we further design a socially efficient model trading and sharing (SEMTS) mechanism. Our mechanism achieves social welfare maximization solely through customer payments, without additional incentive costs. Experimental results on an FL hardware prototype demonstrate up to 148.86%percent148.86148.86\% improvement in social welfare compared to existing mechanisms.

Federated Learning, Mechanism Design, Network Effects

1. Introduction

Federated learning (FL) (Zhan etÂ al., 2022; Tu etÂ al., 2022; Khan etÂ al., 2020) is an emerging machine learning (ML) paradigm that exploits massive data (Nguyen etÂ al., 2021) and resources (Guo etÂ al., 2021) across devices. As a collaborative approach, FL enables clients to enjoy the utility of employing well-trained models through participation, promising to deliver significant social welfare (i.e., the total payoffs for all parties involved (Zeng etÂ al., 2021)). However, given the costs associated with model training, e.g., data labeling and computational costs (Zhao etÂ al., 2023), self-interested clients may hesitate to participate and contribute their resources. Specifically, under existing FL frameworks (e.g., (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Tan etÂ al., 2022; Abdulrahman etÂ al., 2021)), although clients can obtain and utilize the trained model through participation, the utility derived via employing the model could be insufficient to offset their costs, thereby discouraging their participation. With limited client participation, FL struggles to realize the full benefits of collaboration and maximize social welfare. Therefore, from the perspective of system efficiency (Chinchuluun etÂ al., 2008), designing a socially efficient (i.e., social welfare maximizing) mechanism is essential for FL to succeed.

Recent studies have made impressive progress in optimizing social welfare through mechanism design for FL, e.g., (ThiÂ Le etÂ al., 2021; Lin etÂ al., 2022; Lee etÂ al., 2020; Jiao etÂ al., 2021; Saputra etÂ al., 2023; Zhan etÂ al., 2020; Luo etÂ al., 2023; Zhan etÂ al., 2022). However, they often neglect the network effects (Easley and Kleinberg, 2012) arising from client participation. Specifically, network effects111In economics, network effect is a phenomenon where a productâ€™s utility varies with its client number, which often exhibits monotonicity, either positive (i.e., utility increases with clients, as in social networking services) or negative (e.g., network congestion). refer to the interdependence between client participation, trained FL model performance, and corresponding utility, which vary with the network size (participant number). These effects influence the correlation between clientsâ€™ participation decisions. For example, as more clients contribute to FL, training models with higher utility become more feasible, thus attracting even more participants in a positive cycle. Conversely, due to data heterogeneity (Luo etÂ al., 2021), more clients may also yield models with lower utility, discouraging client participation, as depicted in Figure 1. Ignoring such network effects could lead to improper incentive mechanism design at different stages, either underpaying or overpaying clients, failing to adapt to the dynamics of clientsâ€™ participation decisions. Motivated by this, we investigate the following key question in this paper:

Key Question 0.

How to design a socially efficient mechanism for federated learning with network effects?

To address the key question above, we propose a Model Trading and Sharing (MTS) framework

, inspired by the emerging ML model markets (e.g., (Str, [n.â€‰d.]; Gra, [n.â€‰d.])), to exploit network effects in FL and enhance social welfare. The MTS framework, as illustrated in Figure 2, allows clients to obtain and utilize FL models in two ways: by participating in model training as a participant, or by purchasing trained models as a model customer. With this additional purchasing option, FL models are more accessible to clients (e.g., for those with high participation costs or limited data size), and payments from model customers can trigger network effects that promote client participation and increase social welfare.

However, clientsâ€™ strategic decisions prioritize optimizing their individual payoff and potentially deviate from socially optimal decisions. As a result, we need to further design a socially efficient mechanism for the MTS framework, while the unique characteristics of FL with network effects make it highly challenging. Specifically, due to the client data statistical heterogeneity (i.e., data size and distribution heterogeneity (Yan and Ligeti, 2022)) and the distributed nature of FL, quantifying the trained model performance requires complex theoretical models (Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020). This inherent complexity makes it difficult to evaluate network effects by determining the expected model utility and payoff that clients derive from participation. Furthermore, the privacy-preserving feature of FL restricts clients from accessing each otherâ€™s private information, which leads to an incomplete information game, and the extra purchasing option expands clientsâ€™ decision space even further.

Against this background, we first delve into the linear FL models, which are insightful for nonlinear models (Smith etÂ al., 2017; Liang etÂ al., 2020; Hastie etÂ al., 2022; Mei and Montanari, 2022; Krogh and Hertz, 1992). Through the linear model setting and the quantification of network effects on FL model performance, we explore the Nash equilibrium (Mas-Colell etÂ al., 1995) among multiple clients with incomplete information. Building upon these, we design a Socially Efficient Model Trading and Sharing (SEMTS) mechanism that exploits the network effects of client participation. The SEMTS mechanism incentivizes heterogeneous clients to maximize social welfare using only payments from model customers, without incurring extra incentive costs.

This paper advances the state of the art in the following ways:

  • â€¢

    The MTS Framework for FL: To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study on social welfare optimization in FL with network effects. We propose the Model Trading and Sharing (MTS) framework for FL to make models more accessible to clients and enhance social welfare. The MTS framework allows clients to obtain and utilize the trained global FL model either by participating in training or purchasing directly.

  • â€¢

    Network Effects Analysis: Our analysis reveals insights into network effects on heterogeneous client participation and model performance. Counter-intuitively, we show that FL network effects are not monotonic but potentially transit between positive and negative. In scenarios with low data distribution heterogeneity (i.e., non-i.i.d. level of client data), as more clients participate, FL model performance and utility decrease first and then increase. In contrast, with high data distribution heterogeneity, network effects of client participation will exhibit a reverse trend, initially positive but eventually turning negative.

  • â€¢

    Socially Efficient Mechanism Design: Based on the quantification of FL network effects, we derive clientsâ€™ strategic decisions under incomplete information and incorporate them into the mechanism design for the MTS framework. Specifically, we design a Socially Efficient Model Trading and Sharing (SEMTS) mechanism. By exploiting the network effects of client participation, our designed mechanism maximizes social welfare, relying on payments received from model customers rather than incurring extra incentive costs.

  • â€¢

    Experimental Evaluation with Hardware Prototype: We empirically evaluate our proposed mechanism and MTS framework on a hardware prototype of FL. The extensive experiments validate our analysis of network effects in FL and demonstrate that our mechanism can improve social welfare by up to 148.86%percent148.86148.86\%, compared to the theoretical upper bound of existing FL mechanisms that do not consider network effects.

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section 2 reviews related works of mechanism design and network effects in FL. Section 3 introduces the system model and problem formulation. Section 4 presents our proposed MTS framework, which includes the mechanism design through the analysis of network effects. Section 5 provides the experimental evaluation on an FL hardware prototype. We conclude this paper in Section 6. Due to the page limit, we leave detailed proof of our results and extra empirical experiments in the online appendix (Li etÂ al., [n.â€‰d.]).

2. Related Works

The mechanism design for social welfare optimization of FL (e.g., (ThiÂ Le etÂ al., 2021; Lin etÂ al., 2022; Lee etÂ al., 2020; Jiao etÂ al., 2021; Saputra etÂ al., 2023; Zhan etÂ al., 2020; Luo etÂ al., 2023; Liao etÂ al., 5555; Luo etÂ al., 2021)) has made considerable advancements, as summarized in recent surveys (Zhan etÂ al., 2022; Tu etÂ al., 2022; Khan etÂ al., 2020). Specifically, Lee et al. in (Lee etÂ al., 2020) formulated the interaction of participants in FL as a Stackelberg game to maximize social welfare. Jiao et al. in (Jiao etÂ al., 2021) proposed an auction-based market model for incentivizing clients to participate in FL, which can efficiently maximize the social welfare. Saputra et al. in (Saputra etÂ al., 2023) developed a contract-based policy to increase the social welfare of vanilla FL methods. Zhan et al. in (Zhan etÂ al., 2020) evaluated ambiguous contributions in FL through a learning-based algorithm, which improves the overall payoff for participants.

However, these works typically overlook the network effects in FL, which in practice could cause existing mechanisms to either underpay or overpay clients for incentivizing their participation. In contrast, this paper theoretically analyzes the network effects of client participation, which is relatively under-explored and more complex given the unique attributes of FL. By leveraging network effects, our designed mechanism can incentivize clientsâ€™ participation to maximize the social welfare without requiring extra incentives.

The only paper that studies network effects in FL is (Hu etÂ al., 2023) by Hu et al., which investigated the clientâ€™s evolving expectation of FL performance by modeling client behavior as a network effects game. However, this literature focused on the participation equilibrium analysis in FL, without fully considering client heterogeneity and social welfare. Specifically, they assumed that all clients share an expectation about the FL coalition and that client participation will always improve the trained model. In reality, clients often lack information about othersâ€™ decisions, and FL model performance varies with the data statistical heterogeneity. This incomplete information and the impact of heterogeneity could lead their mechanism to fail to incentivize diverse clients for the desired equilibrium. In contrast, this paper designs a mechanism to incentivize the participation of heterogeneous clients with incomplete information, aiming to maximize the social welfare in FL.

3. System Model and Problem Formulation

In this section, we begin by introducing the fundamentals of FL and modeling heterogeneous clients. Then, we specify our proposed MTS framework and formulate the mechanism design problem for social welfare optimization within it.

3.1. Preliminaries of Federated Learning

FL is a distributed ML paradigm that leverages multiple clientsâ€™ resources to collaboratively train a shared model. To illustrate how FL works, we first provide an overview of the FL training process.

We consider a set of clients ğ’©={1,2,â‹¯,N}ğ’©12â‹¯ğ‘\mathcal{N}=\{1,2,\cdots,N\} interested in FL model training, which involves Nğ‘N clients with heterogeneous characteristics. By participating in the training process, clients can obtain and utilize the trained global FL model. However, the FL model training process also incurs related costs for participants, e.g., due to resource consumption and data processing. Consequently, the self-interested Nğ‘N clients may not fully participate in FL.

After introducing the preliminaries of FL, we then present heterogeneous clients interested in implementing FL.

3.2. Heterogeneous Clients Modeling

This subsection describes heterogeneous characteristics of clients, along with their participation cost and model utility.

3.2.3. FL Model Utility

According to research on ML model markets (Chen etÂ al., 2019b; Liu etÂ al., 2021; Agarwal etÂ al., 2019), the clientâ€™s utility of employing the FL model relies heavily on how well it performs on future (unseen) data, i.e., the modelâ€™s generalization ability, quantified by the generalization error Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon. 3.3. The MTS Frameworks of Federated Learning

While clients can enjoy FL model utility by participating in training, the associated participation costs may discourage some of them. To enhance model accessibility and exploit the network effects, we propose a Model Trading and Sharing (MTS) framework, which introduces an extra purchasing option for clients to obtain the trained model. In this subsection, we elaborate on the MTS framework, focusing on the decision space and the payoff of clients within it.

3.3.1. Client Decision

Under the MTS framework, heterogeneous clients have three available strategies: abstain from obtaining the FL model, participate555To deliver clear insights, we focus on full participation behaviors of clients rather than partial ones (i.e., randomly joining some rounds of FL training), where the latter will yield similar analytical results, as studied in (Wang and Ji, 2024; Yang etÂ al., 2021). in the training process to obtain the FL model, or directly purchase the well-trained FL model. We denote the strategies of client nâˆˆğ’©iğ‘›subscriptğ’©ğ‘–n\in\mathcal{N}_{i} with any type iâˆˆâ„ğ‘–â„i\in\mathcal{I} as snâˆˆ{A,J,B}subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›ğ´ğ½ğµs_{n}\in\{A,J,B\}, i.e.,

(4a) sn=subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›absent\displaystyle s_{n}= A,ğ´\displaystyle A, abstain from obtaining the FL model,
(4b) sn=subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›absent\displaystyle s_{n}= J,ğ½\displaystyle J, join FL to obtain the model,
(4c) sn=subscriptğ‘ ğ‘›absent\displaystyle s_{n}= B,ğµ\displaystyle B, buy the FL model.

3.3.2. FL Model Price and Participation Reward

As illustrated in Figure 2, the MTS framework includes a platform that coordinates the FL model training and trading process. This platform enables heterogeneous clients to obtain the model by paying or, alternatively, by participating in training with a participation reward. We use pğ‘p to represent the price of the trained global FL model and denote risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i} as the participation reward for type-iğ‘–i clients. In order to focus on the socially efficient mechanism design for FL with network effects, we assume such a platform is non-profit666For the platform operating on a cost-recovery basis, the analysis is the same but incorporates the platformâ€™s associated costs into social welfare. and aims to maximize the social welfare. That is, the platform only leverages all payments received from model customers to incentivize client participation and model improvements in FL, i.e.,

(5) âˆ‘iâˆˆâ„Biâ€‹p=âˆ‘iâˆˆâ„Kiâ€‹ri.subscriptğ‘–â„subscriptğµğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğ‘–â„subscriptğ¾ğ‘–subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–\sum\nolimits_{i\in\mathcal{I}}B_{i}p=\sum\nolimits_{i\in\mathcal{I}}K_{i}r_{i}.

Note that the participation reward risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i}, for any iâˆˆâ„ğ‘–â„i\in\mathcal{I}, could be negative, which serves to penalize the participation of clients with poor contributions to the FL model performance and compensate other high-contributing participants.

3.3.3. Client Payoff

The payoff Ï€nsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘›\pi_{n} of a type-iğ‘–i client nâˆˆğ’©iğ‘›subscriptğ’©ğ‘–n\in\mathcal{N}_{i}, for any iâˆˆâ„ğ‘–â„i\in\mathcal{I}, within the MTS framework is a function of all clientsâ€™ decisions, which also involves the model utility Uâ€‹(Ïµ)ğ‘ˆitalic-ÏµU(\epsilon), participation cost Cisubscriptğ¶ğ‘–C_{i}, participation reward risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i}, and model price pğ‘p. To simplify the notation, we denote the vector of all clientsâ€™ strategies (i.e., snsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›s_{n} for all nâˆˆğ’©ğ‘›ğ’©n\in\mathcal{N}) as ğ’”ğ’”\boldsymbol{s}, and summarize the payoff function of client nğ‘›n with type iâˆˆâ„ğ‘–â„i\in\mathcal{I} as follows:

(6a) Ï€nâ€‹(ğ’”)=subscriptğœ‹ğ‘›ğ’”absent\displaystyle\pi_{n}(\boldsymbol{s})= 0,0\displaystyle 0, if sn=Asubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›ğ´s_{n}=A,
(6b) Ï€nâ€‹(ğ’”)=subscriptğœ‹ğ‘›ğ’”absent\displaystyle\pi_{n}(\boldsymbol{s})= Uâ€‹(Ïµ)âˆ’Ci+ri,ğ‘ˆitalic-Ïµsubscriptğ¶ğ‘–subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–\displaystyle U(\epsilon)-C_{i}+r_{i}, if sn=Jsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›ğ½s_{n}=J,
(6c) Ï€nâ€‹(ğ’”)=subscriptğœ‹ğ‘›ğ’”absent\displaystyle\pi_{n}(\boldsymbol{s})= Uâ€‹(Ïµ)âˆ’p,ğ‘ˆitalic-Ïµğ‘\displaystyle U(\epsilon)-p, if sn=Bsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›ğµs_{n}=B.

From (6a), if client nğ‘›n abstains from acquiring the trained global FL model, the payoff Ï€nsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘›\pi_{n} is zero. By participating in the FL model training process, the type-iğ‘–i client nâˆˆğ’©iğ‘›subscriptğ’©ğ‘–n\in\mathcal{N}_{i} will obtain the model utility Uâ€‹(Ïµ)ğ‘ˆitalic-ÏµU(\epsilon) and participation reward risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i} while incurring the participation cost Cisubscriptğ¶ğ‘–C_{i}, as stated in (6b). When the client nğ‘›n decides to purchase the trained FL model directly, the payoff Ï€nsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘›\pi_{n} is the difference between model utility Uâ€‹(Ïµ)ğ‘ˆitalic-ÏµU(\epsilon) and model price pğ‘p, as expressed in (6c).

With the proposed MTS framework, we aim to optimize the social welfare in FL. Given the platformâ€™s non-profit nature, as detailed in Section 3.3.2, the payoff of the platform will always be zero. That is, the objective of social welfare maximization is consistent with the maximization of clientsâ€™ total payoff. To this end, we next formulate the mechanism design problem for social welfare optimization.

3.4. Socially Efficient Mechanism Design Problem

To maximize the FL social welfare, the mechanism design problem under the MTS framework entails optimizing both FL model price pğ‘p and participation reward risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i}, for any iâˆˆâ„ğ‘–â„i\in\mathcal{I}, as elaborated below.

For a set of clients ğ’©ğ’©\mathcal{N} interested in the FL model under the MTS framework, the payoff of the platform is zero, and thus the social welfare WMTSsubscriptğ‘ŠMTSW_{\textrm{MTS}} is the sum of each clientâ€™s payoff Ï€nsubscriptğœ‹ğ‘›\pi_{n} in (6c), related to all clientsâ€™ strategies. Given the number of participants Kisubscriptğ¾ğ‘–K_{i} and model customers Bisubscriptğµğ‘–B_{i} of each client type iâˆˆâ„ğ‘–â„i\in\mathcal{I}, we can express the social welfare WMTSsubscriptğ‘ŠMTSW_{\textrm{MTS}} as follows:

(7) WMTS=âˆ‘iâˆˆâ„[Kiâ€‹(Uâ€‹(Ïµ)âˆ’Ci+ri)+Biâ€‹(Uâ€‹(Ïµ)âˆ’p)].subscriptğ‘ŠMTSsubscriptğ‘–â„delimited-[]subscriptğ¾ğ‘–ğ‘ˆitalic-Ïµsubscriptğ¶ğ‘–subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–subscriptğµğ‘–ğ‘ˆitalic-Ïµğ‘W_{\textrm{MTS}}=\sum\nolimits_{i\in\mathcal{I}}[K_{i}(U(\epsilon)-C_{i}+r_{i})+B_{i}(U(\epsilon)-p)].

According to WMTSsubscriptğ‘ŠMTSW_{\textrm{MTS}} in (7) and considering clientsâ€™ self-interested decision-making, i.e., making decisions that maximize their individual payoff, we formulate the mechanism design problem of social welfare optimization as Problem 1.

In the following section, we will design a socially efficient mechanism under the MTS framework to solve Problem 1. The mechanism takes into account both the FL model performance and the number of benefiting clients, leveraging the network effects of client participation to maximize the social welfare.

4. Mechanism Design with Network Effects

We first theoretically analyze the FL network effects. Then, building upon this analysis, we study the social efficiency of the MTS framework and propose the mechanism that maximizes social welfare.

4.1. Network Effects of Client Participation

FL enables clients to collaboratively train and share a model with the aim of generating accurate outputs for a particular task. Based on the generalization error Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon derived in (3), we begin by exploring the impact of client collaboration in FL, as summarized in Corollary 4.1, in order to understand the network effects of client participation.

Corollary 0.

Consider two disjoint non-empty participant coalitions ğ’¦asubscriptğ’¦ğ‘\mathcal{K}_{a} and ğ’¦bsubscriptğ’¦ğ‘\mathcal{K}_{b}, where Hasubscriptğ»ğ‘H_{a} and Hbsubscriptğ»ğ‘H_{b} are the harmonic means of participantsâ€™ data sizes in ğ’¦asubscriptğ’¦ğ‘\mathcal{K}_{a} and ğ’¦bsubscriptğ’¦ğ‘\mathcal{K}_{b}, with Haâ‰¤Hbsubscriptğ»ğ‘subscriptğ»ğ‘H_{a}\leq H_{b}. The generalization error Ïµasubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘\epsilon_{a} and Ïµbsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘\epsilon_{b} of the model trained by ğ’¦asubscriptğ’¦ğ‘\mathcal{K}_{a} and ğ’¦bsubscriptğ’¦ğ‘\mathcal{K}_{b} satisfies Ïµa+b<maxâ¡{Ïµa,Ïµb}subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘ğ‘subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘\epsilon_{a+b}<\max\{\epsilon_{a},\epsilon_{b}\}, if and only if Ïƒ2Î³2<Hbâ€‹Kb+Kaâ€‹(2â€‹Hbâˆ’Ha)Haâ€‹Hbâ€‹(Ka+Kb)/dsuperscriptğœ2superscriptğ›¾2subscriptğ»ğ‘subscriptğ¾ğ‘subscriptğ¾ğ‘2subscriptğ»ğ‘subscriptğ»ğ‘subscriptğ»ğ‘subscriptğ»ğ‘subscriptğ¾ğ‘subscriptğ¾ğ‘ğ‘‘\frac{\sigma^{2}}{\gamma^{2}}<\frac{H_{b}K_{b}+K_{a}(2H_{b}-H_{a})}{H_{a}H_{b}(K_{a}+K_{b})/d}, where Ïµa+bsubscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘ğ‘\epsilon_{a+b} is the generalization error of the model trained by ğ’¦aâˆªğ’¦bsubscriptğ’¦ğ‘subscriptğ’¦ğ‘\mathcal{K}_{a}\cup\mathcal{K}_{b}.

Corollary 4.1 implies that client collaboration in FL can benefit individual participants (or coalitions of multiple participants) by enabling them to obtain a model with lower generalization error Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon compared to training alone. Nevertheless, collaboration is not always beneficial to all participants, especially when client variance Ïƒ2superscriptğœ2\sigma^{2} outweighs data variance Î³2superscriptğ›¾2\gamma^{2} beyond a certain threshold. In such cases, the participation of a client could increase the generalization error of the FL model trained by existing participants. This decline in model performance reduces model utility for existing participants, exhibiting negative network effects of client participation in FL.

To thoroughly investigate the varying network effects of client participation, we quantify it in terms of the change in the generalization error Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon of the trained FL model caused by client participation, as defined in Definition 4.2. Then, we derive conditions under which FL network effects are non-negative, established in Theorem 1.

Definition 0 (Network Effects (Easley and Kleinberg, 2012) of Client Participation).

Given any non-empty coalition of existing participants ğ’¦ğ’¦\mathcal{K}, the participation of a client nğ‘›n results in network effects manifested as the difference between the generalization error of the FL model trained by ğ’¦ğ’¦\mathcal{K} and the generalization error of the model trained by ğ’¦âˆª{n}ğ’¦ğ‘›\mathcal{K}\cup\{n\}, expressed as Ïµâ€‹(ğ’¦)âˆ’Ïµâ€‹(ğ’¦âˆª{n})italic-Ïµğ’¦italic-Ïµğ’¦ğ‘›\epsilon(\mathcal{K})-\epsilon(\mathcal{K}\cup\{n\}).

However, the composition of participants changes with the participation of new clients, which in turn will affect the specific data size threshold required for future new clients to ensure non-negative network effects from their participation.

Given the above discussions, heterogeneous participants are intertwined to affect the performance of the FL model and the network effects of client participation. To demonstrate how FL model performance and network effects vary with the number of participants from different types, we first take I=2ğ¼2I=2 types of clients, each possessing homogeneous data sets (i.e., Ïƒ2=0superscriptğœ20\sigma^{2}=0), as an illustrative example, shown in Example 4.3.

Example 0 (Two Types of Clients).

Consider I=2ğ¼2I=2 types of clients with Ïƒ2=0superscriptğœ20\sigma^{2}=0 in FL, and a coalition of participant ğ’¦ğ’¦\mathcal{K}. As the number K1subscriptğ¾1K_{1} of type-111 participants in ğ’¦ğ’¦\mathcal{K} increases, the generalization error Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon of the trained global FL model initially increases, but eventually decreases once K1â‰¥âŒˆ(âˆ’2â€‹K2â€‹D1âˆ’D2+4â€‹K22â€‹(D2âˆ’D1)2+D22)/2â€‹D2âŒ‰subscriptğ¾12subscriptğ¾2subscriptğ·1subscriptğ·24superscriptsubscriptğ¾22superscriptsubscriptğ·2subscriptğ·12superscriptsubscriptğ·222subscriptğ·2K_{1}\geq\lceil{({-2K_{2}D_{1}-D_{2}+\sqrt{4K_{2}^{2}(D_{2}-D_{1})^{2}+D_{2}^{2}}})/{2D_{2}}}\rceil. In contrast, the generalization error consistently decreases as the number K2subscriptğ¾2K_{2} of type-222 participants in ğ’¦ğ’¦\mathcal{K} grows.

Example 4.3 provides an interesting insight under the i.i.d. data distribution: when the number of participants with small data size falls below a certain threshold (as referred to type-111 clients in Example 4.3), their participation will incur negative network effects; however, once the number of these participants exceeds the threshold, their participation will yield positive network effects. In contrast, the participation of clients with the largest data size brings positive network effects, regardless of the number of such participants.

After introducing the case of two client types and i.i.d. data distribution, we extend our analysis to general scenarios with Iğ¼I client types and non-i.i.d. data distribution, as elaborated in Theorem 2.

We give the proof of Theorem 2 in online appendix (Li etÂ al., [n.â€‰d.]). From Theorem 2, network effects of type-jğ‘—j client participation not only depend on heterogeneity ratio Ïƒ2/Î³2superscriptğœ2superscriptğ›¾2\sigma^{2}/\gamma^{2} and data size Djsubscriptğ·ğ‘—D_{j}, but also potentially vary with the number of type-jğ‘—j participants, for any jâˆˆâ„ğ‘—â„j\in\mathcal{I}. Specifically, we can divide the network effects of client participation into four regions, as depicted in Figure 3. In Region \nbRoman1, the trained FL model performance (and model utility) first increases and then decreases with the growing number of participants of the same type. In contrast, for Region \nbRoman2, the network effects are always positive, reducing the generalization error Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon of the FL model. Region \nbRoman3 and Region \nbRoman4, however, exhibit reverse trends of network effects in Region \nbRoman2 and Region \nbRoman1, respectively. As a result, given any participant coalition ğ’¦â‰ âˆ…ğ’¦\mathcal{K}\neq\emptyset and heterogeneity ratio Ïƒ2/Î³2superscriptğœ2superscriptğ›¾2\sigma^{2}/\gamma^{2}, we can determine the network effects for different client types. For example, when Ïƒ2=0superscriptğœ20\sigma^{2}=0 (representing an i.i.d. data distribution, as indicated by line Oâ€‹Ağ‘‚ğ´OA in Figure 3), the network effects will correspond to Regions \nbRoman3 or \nbRoman4, consistent with our observation in Example 4.3.

So far, through the theoretical analysis of FL model performance, we have investigated network effects arising from the participation of heterogeneous clients. Next, we delve into the social efficiency of the MTS framework, in order to develop a corresponding mechanism that maximizes social welfare.

4.2. Social Efficiency of the MTS Framework

The social welfare (Zeng etÂ al., 2021) characterizes the total payoff for all parties involved. Under the MTS framework, the platformâ€™s payoff is always zero, detailed in Section 3.3.2, and thus, the social welfare is the sum of each clientâ€™s payoff. As formulated by WMTSsubscriptğ‘ŠMTSW_{\textrm{MTS}} in (7), the social welfare of the MTS framework depends on each client decision snsubscriptğ‘ ğ‘›s_{n} and the resultant FL model performance (quantified by generalization error). Through the generalization error Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon of the FL model derived in (3), WMTSsubscriptğ‘ŠMTSW_{\textrm{MTS}} is a function of the number of heterogeneous participants and model customers, corresponding to different FL social states (Easley and Kleinberg, 2012) introduced in Definition 4.4.

Definition 0 (Social State (Easley and Kleinberg, 2012) of FL).

Consider a group of clients with a set of pure strategies {A,J,B}ğ´ğ½ğµ\{A,J,B\} in (4c). A social state is a vector {ğŠ,ğ}ğŠğ\{\boldsymbol{K},\boldsymbol{B}\} gives the number Kisubscriptğ¾ğ‘–K_{i} and Bisubscriptğµğ‘–B_{i} of type-iğ‘–i clients with strategy Jğ½J and BğµB respectively, for all iâˆˆâ„ğ‘–â„i\in\mathcal{I}.

To determine optimal social welfare and design an appropriate mechanism, we explore the social efficiency of the MTS framework, with an emphasis on socially efficient states in Definition 4.5. We begin by summarizing the features of socially efficient states under the MTS framework in Lemma 1.

Definition 0 (Socially Efficient States).

Lemma 1.

In socially efficient states under the MTS framework, either no clients obtain the FL model, i.e., âˆ‘iâˆˆâ„(Kiâˆ—+Biâˆ—)=0subscriptğ‘–â„subscriptsuperscriptğ¾ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğµğ‘–0\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}(K^{*}_{i}+B^{*}_{i})=0, or all of them obtain it, i.e., âˆ‘iâˆˆâ„(Kiâˆ—+Biâˆ—)=Nsubscriptğ‘–â„subscriptsuperscriptğ¾ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğµğ‘–ğ‘\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}(K^{*}_{i}+B^{*}_{i})=N.

Lemma 1 implies the only two possibilities for the socially efficient states under the MTS framework. If the optimal social welfare WMTSâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ‘ŠMTSW_{\textrm{MTS}}^{*} is zero, the minimum possible value, then {ğ‘²âˆ—,ğ‘©âˆ—}=ğŸsuperscriptğ‘²superscriptğ‘©0\{\boldsymbol{K}^{*},\boldsymbol{B}^{*}\}=\boldsymbol{0} must be a socially efficient state, that is, âˆ‘iâˆˆâ„(Kiâˆ—+Biâˆ—)=0subscriptğ‘–â„subscriptsuperscriptğ¾ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğµğ‘–0\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}(K^{*}_{i}+B^{*}_{i})=0. When the optimal social welfare WMTSâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ‘ŠMTSW_{\textrm{MTS}}^{*} under the MTS framework is larger than zero, the socially efficient states will satisfy âˆ‘iâˆˆâ„(Kiâˆ—+Biâˆ—)=Nsubscriptğ‘–â„subscriptsuperscriptğ¾ğ‘–subscriptsuperscriptğµğ‘–ğ‘\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}(K^{*}_{i}+B^{*}_{i})=N, indicating that all clients will obtain the trained global FL model, either by participating in training or purchasing it directly.

Building upon the above discussions, we proceed to study the socially efficient states with positive optimal social welfare, which is the transformation of Problem 1 and aligns with its objective function. We formulate such a socially efficient states problem as Problem 2, incorporating the generalization error Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon in (3). The socially efficient states addressed in Problem 2 will indicate strategies that mechanism for solving Problem 1 aims to incentivize clients to adopt. This establishes the foundation for us to design the mechanism that optimizes social welfare under the MTS framework later.

When dealing with Problem 2, due to the varying network effects, we divide the type set â„â„\mathcal{I} of heterogeneous clients into two distinct subsets: â„Lsubscriptâ„ğ¿\mathcal{I}_{L} (low type index) and â„Hsubscriptâ„ğ»\mathcal{I}_{H} (high type index). Such categorization is based on two key factors that affect the network effects of client participation, i.e., client data size Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i} and heterogeneity ratio Ïƒ2/Î³2superscriptğœ2superscriptğ›¾2\sigma^{2}/\gamma^{2}, as elaborated in Theorem 2. For clients with type iâˆˆâ„Lğ‘–subscriptâ„ğ¿i\in\mathcal{I}_{L}, their data size satisfies that Diâ‰¤dâ€‹Î³2/Ïƒ2subscriptğ·ğ‘–ğ‘‘superscriptğ›¾2superscriptğœ2D_{i}\leq d\gamma^{2}/\sigma^{2}, whereas the data size of clients with type jâˆˆâ„Hğ‘—subscriptâ„ğ»j\in\mathcal{I}_{H} is larger than dâ€‹Î³2/Ïƒ2ğ‘‘superscriptğ›¾2superscriptğœ2d\gamma^{2}/\sigma^{2}. By separately analyzing these two sets of clients, we determine the participation pattern of clients in the socially efficient states that yield positive optimal social welfare WMTSâˆ—>0superscriptsubscriptğ‘ŠMTS0W_{\textrm{MTS}}^{*}>0, concluded in Proposition 4.6.

Proposition 0.

    if â„H=âˆ…subscriptâ„ğ»\mathcal{I}_{H}=\emptyset, then Kiâˆ—âˆˆ{0,Ni}superscriptsubscriptğ¾ğ‘–0subscriptğ‘ğ‘–K_{i}^{*}\in\{0,N_{i}\}, âˆ€iâˆˆâ„Lfor-allğ‘–subscriptâ„ğ¿\forall i\in\mathcal{I}_{L}.

  • â€¢

    if â„Hâ‰ âˆ…subscriptâ„ğ»\mathcal{I}_{H}\neq\emptyset, then Kiâˆ—=0superscriptsubscriptğ¾ğ‘–0K_{i}^{*}=0, âˆ€iâˆˆâ„Lfor-allğ‘–subscriptâ„ğ¿\forall i\in\mathcal{I}_{L}, and Kjâˆ—âˆˆ{0,Nj}âˆª{Kjâˆˆâ„•:âˆ‚WMTSâ€‹(Kj)/âˆ‚Kj=0}superscriptsubscriptğ¾ğ‘—0subscriptğ‘ğ‘—conditional-setsubscriptğ¾ğ‘—â„•subscriptğ‘ŠMTSsubscriptğ¾ğ‘—subscriptğ¾ğ‘—0K_{j}^{*}\in\{0,N_{j}\}\cup\{K_{j}\in\mathbb{N}:{\partial W_{\textrm{MTS}}(K_{j})}/{\partial K_{j}}=0\}, âˆ€jâˆˆâ„Hfor-allğ‘—subscriptâ„ğ»\forall j\in\mathcal{I}_{H}.

Proposition 4.6 reveals that socially efficient states typically exhibit an â€œall-or-noneâ€ participation pattern for any client type. However, for clients with type jâˆˆâ„Hğ‘—subscriptâ„ğ»j\in\mathcal{I}_{H}, partial participation in training can also lead to socially efficient states. The underlying rationale is consistent with Theorem 2. Specifically, according to Figure 3, clients of type iâˆˆâ„Lğ‘–subscriptâ„ğ¿i\in\mathcal{I}_{L} will fall into Region \nbRoman2 and Region \nbRoman4, while clients of type jâˆˆâ„Hğ‘—subscriptâ„ğ»j\in\mathcal{I}_{H} will occupy Region \nbRoman1 and Region \nbRoman3. Consequently, in socially efficient states, type-iğ‘–i clients will either all participate in training to exploit the positive network effects, or all abstain from training to avoid incurring negative network effects. In contrast, clients of type jâˆˆâ„Hğ‘—subscriptâ„ğ»j\in\mathcal{I}_{H} demonstrate an additional possibility for socially efficient states: only part of the clients participate in training, sufficient to reap positive network effects but not so much as to trigger negative ones (i.e., reaching the threshold of participant number Kjâˆ—={Kjâˆˆâ„•:âˆ‚WMTSâ€‹(Kj)/âˆ‚Kj=0}subscriptsuperscriptğ¾ğ‘—conditional-setsubscriptğ¾ğ‘—â„•subscriptğ‘ŠMTSsubscriptğ¾ğ‘—subscriptğ¾ğ‘—0K^{*}_{j}=\{K_{j}\in\mathbb{N}:{\partial W_{\textrm{MTS}}(K_{j})}/{\partial K_{j}}=0\} that network effects turn from positive to negative).

To summarize, in scenarios with low data distribution heterogeneity (where Ïƒ2â‰¤dâ€‹Î³2/DIsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘‘superscriptğ›¾2subscriptğ·ğ¼\sigma^{2}\leq d\gamma^{2}/D_{I}, implying that â„H=âˆ…subscriptâ„ğ»\mathcal{I}_{H}=\emptyset), clients of the same type must make consistent participation decisions to maximize the social welfare under the MTS framework, i.e., Kiâˆ—=0superscriptsubscriptğ¾ğ‘–0K_{i}^{*}=0 or Kiâˆ—=Nisubscriptsuperscriptğ¾ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–K^{*}_{i}=N_{i}, for any type iâˆˆâ„Lğ‘–subscriptâ„ğ¿i\in\mathcal{I}_{L}. Conversely, with high data distribution heterogeneity (where Ïƒ2>dâ€‹Î³2/DIsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘‘superscriptğ›¾2subscriptğ·ğ¼\sigma^{2}>d\gamma^{2}/D_{I}, implying that â„Hâ‰ âˆ…subscriptâ„ğ»\mathcal{I}_{H}\neq\emptyset), socially efficient states will not involve participants of type iâˆˆâ„Lğ‘–subscriptâ„ğ¿i\in\mathcal{I}_{L}, and only clients of type jâˆˆâ„Hğ‘—subscriptâ„ğ»j\in\mathcal{I}_{H} potentially participate in FL.

After investigating socially efficient states {ğ‘²âˆ—,ğ‘©âˆ—}superscriptğ‘²superscriptğ‘©\{\boldsymbol{K}^{*},\boldsymbol{B}^{*}\}, we compare the resultant optimal social welfare WMTSâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ŠMTSW^{*}_{\textrm{MTS}} under our proposed MTS framework to that of the existing FL framework WFLâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ŠFLW^{*}_{\textrm{FL}}. Unlike the MTS framework, the existing FL framework (e.g., (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Tan etÂ al., 2022; Abdulrahman etÂ al., 2021)) only allows clients to obtain and utilize the FL model by participating in the training process, resulting in the social welfare WFLsubscriptğ‘ŠFLW_{\textrm{FL}} below:

(9) WFLâ€‹(ğ‘²)=âˆ‘iâˆˆâ„Kiâ€‹(Uâ€‹(Ïµ)âˆ’Ci).subscriptğ‘ŠFLğ‘²subscriptğ‘–â„subscriptğ¾ğ‘–ğ‘ˆitalic-Ïµsubscriptğ¶ğ‘–W_{\textrm{FL}}(\boldsymbol{K})=\sum\nolimits_{i\in\mathcal{I}}K_{i}\left(U(\epsilon)-C_{i}\right).

In contrast, the MTS framework enables clients to access the model through an extra purchasing option, which leads to the social welfare WMTSsubscriptğ‘ŠMTSW_{\textrm{MTS}} in (7). As a result, our proposed MTS framework ensures that the optimal social welfare WMTSâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ŠMTSW^{*}_{\textrm{MTS}} is no less than that of the existing FL framework WFLâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ŠFLW^{*}_{\textrm{FL}}, as presented in Proposition 4.7.

Proposition 0.

Given any client set ğ’©ğ’©\mathcal{N}, the optimal social welfare achieved by the MTS framework WMTSâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ŠMTSW^{*}_{\textrm{MTS}} is no less than that of the existing FL framework WFLâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ŠFLW^{*}_{\textrm{FL}}, i.e., WMTSâˆ—â‰¥WFLâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ŠMTSsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ŠFLW^{*}_{\textrm{MTS}}\geq W^{*}_{\textrm{FL}}.

Following the analysis of social efficiency under our proposed MTS framework, we next address its practical implementation. We aim to design a mechanism for the MTS framework that leads self-interested clients, who prioritize optimizing their individual payoffs and thus potentially deviate from socially efficient states, to maximize the social welfare.

4.3. Socially Efficient Mechanism Design

The problem of socially efficient mechanism design under the MTS framework, as formulated in Problem 1, entails the optimization of FL model price pğ‘p and the participation reward risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i} for type-iğ‘–i clients.

From Lemma 1 and Proposition 4.6, socially efficient states, due to network effects, require clients of each type iâˆˆâ„ğ‘–â„i\in\mathcal{I} to transit between specific social states in a way that maximizes social welfare. For instance, in scenarios with low data distribution heterogeneity Ïƒ2â‰¤dâ€‹Î³2/DIsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘‘superscriptğ›¾2subscriptğ·ğ¼\sigma^{2}\leq d\gamma^{2}/D_{I}, the socially efficient state is Kiâˆ—âˆˆ{0,Ni}superscriptsubscriptğ¾ğ‘–0subscriptğ‘ğ‘–K_{i}^{*}\in\{0,N_{i}\}. However, each client nâˆˆğ’©iğ‘›subscriptğ’©ğ‘–n\in\mathcal{N}_{i}, irrespective of their type iâˆˆâ„ğ‘–â„i\in\mathcal{I}, will seek to make decision snâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ ğ‘›s^{*}_{n} that optimizes individual payoff Ï€nâˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğœ‹ğ‘›\pi^{*}_{n} in (6c) under the MTS framework, rather than social welfare. Meanwhile, the initial negative network effects, as elaborated in Theorem 2, also prevent self-interested clients from reaching socially efficient states, thereby significantly complicating Problem 1. In response to these challenges, we propose a Socially Efficient Model Trading and Sharing (SEMTS) mechanism, which aligns client payoff with social welfare while accounting for the network effects of client participation, as detailed below.

To maximize the social welfare under the MTS framework, we incentivize heterogeneous clients to overcome the negative network effects phase and exploit positive network effects. Specifically, corresponding to Proposition 4.6, the SEMTS mechanism includes considerations based on distinct data distribution heterogeneity (i.e., different non-i.i.d. levels). For scenarios with low data distribution heterogeneity Ïƒ2â‰¤dâ€‹Î³2/DIsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘‘superscriptğ›¾2subscriptğ·ğ¼\sigma^{2}\leq d\gamma^{2}/D_{I}, we construct a function Î¸â€‹(ğ‘²)ğœƒğ‘²\theta(\boldsymbol{K}) in (4.3) for all clients in the intermediate social states (i.e., 0<Ki<Ni0subscriptğ¾ğ‘–subscriptğ‘ğ‘–0<K_{i}<N_{i}, for any iâˆˆâ„ğ‘–â„i\in\mathcal{I}), defined as follows:

Î¸â€‹(ğ‘²)=ğœƒğ‘²absent\displaystyle\theta(\boldsymbol{K})= âˆ‘iâˆˆâ„(Niâˆ’KiNiâ€‹IU(Ïµ(Ki=0))\displaystyle\sum\nolimits_{i\in\mathcal{I}}\left(\right.\frac{N_{i}-K_{i}}{N_{i}I}U(\epsilon(K_{i}=0))
(10) âˆ’KiNiâ€‹IU(Ïµ(Ki=Ni))âˆ’Kiâ€‹CiN).\displaystyle-\frac{K_{i}}{N_{i}I}U(\epsilon(K_{i}=N_{i}))-\frac{K_{i}C_{i}}{N}\left.\right).

The function Î¸â€‹(ğ‘²)ğœƒğ‘²\theta(\boldsymbol{K}) in (4.3) derives the average payoff of clients in socially efficient states and makes transitions among intermediate social states consistent with individual payoff maximization. In particular, when the participation of clients contributes to achieving socially efficient states, their payoff with the structure in (4.3) will ensure positive network effects (i.e., increase the individual payoff of all participants), and vice versa. In contrast, for scenarios with high data distribution heterogeneity Ïƒ2>dâ€‹Î³2/DIsuperscriptğœ2ğ‘‘superscriptğ›¾2subscriptğ·ğ¼\sigma^{2}>d\gamma^{2}/D_{I}, the SEMTS mechanism focuses on ensuring a non-negative payoff for each participant, in order to initiate positive network effects. We conclude the details of the SEMTS mechanism in the following, which avoids discouraging client participation due to temporary negative network effects or negative payoff.

Mechanism 0 (The SEMTS Mechanism).

The SEMTS mechanism is as follows:

With the model price pğ‘p and participation reward risubscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–r_{i} designed in the SEMTS mechanism, given any social state, the optimal decisions of all self-interested clients align with maximizing social welfare. Each client will make the decision to promote social welfare, i.e., as a participant or model customer that leads to socially efficient states, regardless of any other clientâ€™s decision (after considering the coupling with other clients). Furthermore, once clients reach socially efficient states, they benefit from positive network effects without relying on any constructed function, e.g., Î¸â€‹(ğ‘²)ğœƒğ‘²\theta(\boldsymbol{K}). This implies that our mechanism can operate solely on payments from FL model customers rather than requiring extra incentives. We summarize the properties of the SEMTS mechanism in Theorem 3, and give the detailed proof in the online appendix (Li etÂ al., [n.â€‰d.]).

Theorem 3.

The SEMTS mechanism leads to the socially efficient states {ğŠâˆ—,ğâˆ—}superscriptğŠsuperscriptğ\{\boldsymbol{K}^{*},\boldsymbol{B}^{*}\} and achieves optimal social welfare WMTSâˆ—superscriptsubscriptğ‘ŠMTSW_{\textrm{MTS}}^{*} under the MTS framework, which operates without incurring extra incentive costs, i.e., âˆ‘iâˆˆâ„Biâ€‹p=âˆ‘iâˆˆâ„Kiâ€‹risubscriptğ‘–â„subscriptğµğ‘–ğ‘subscriptğ‘–â„subscriptğ¾ğ‘–subscriptğ‘Ÿğ‘–\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}B_{i}p=\sum_{i\in\mathcal{I}}K_{i}r_{i}.

Overall, we have analyzed the network effects of client participation in FL and established an SEMTS mechanism for maximizing social welfare under the MTS framework. Next, we will empirically evaluate our theoretical results through extensive experiments on an FL hardware prototype.

5. Experimental Evaluation

This section begins by introducing the experimental setup. Then, we present empirical results to demonstrate our investigation of FL network effects and evaluate the social efficiency of our proposed SEMTS mechanism and MTS framework.

5.1. Experimental Setup

5.1.1. Hardware Prototype of FL

To better characterize real-world applications, we carry out our experiments on a hardware prototype of FL, as shown in Figure 4. The FL hardware prototype consists of 202020 Raspberry Pis that serve as clients, along with a desktop computer that functions as the central server for coordination (i.e., the platform in Figure 2). The client and server communication occurs through a Wi-Fi router using a TCP-based socket interface.

5.1.2. Heterogeneous Clients and Learning Implementation

We consider a set of N=20ğ‘20N=20 heterogeneous clients interested in the FL model. For ease of illustration777While we only present experimental results under this setting due to the page limit, the insights for other function types of model utility and participation cost are similar., we define the FL model utility function of clients as Uâ€‹(Ïµ)=40â‹…Ïµâˆ’16ğ‘ˆitalic-Ïµâ‹…40superscriptitalic-Ïµ16U(\epsilon)=40\cdot\epsilon^{-16}, and the participation cost of clients is proportional to their training data size. To simulate the heterogeneity among clients, we categorize 202020 clients into I=3ğ¼3I=3 types: 101010 type-111 clients, five types-222 clients, and five type-333 clients. Moreover, we use the widely adopted MNIST (Lecun etÂ al., 1998) and CIFAR-10 (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009) data sets in our experiments888We also conduct experiments on the CIFAR-100 (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009) and SVHN (Netzer etÂ al., 2011) data sets, which have similar results, as demonstrated in the online appendix (Li etÂ al., [n.â€‰d.])., which contain 70,0007000070,000 grayscale images of handwritten digits and 60,0006000060,000 color images of objects, respectively. Table 1 summarizes the training data size Disubscriptğ·ğ‘–D_{i} of each client type iâˆˆâ„ğ‘–â„i\in\mathcal{I}, as well as the testing data size used to evaluate the trained global FL model performance. While we focus on this small-scale setup, the insights are the same for a larger number of clients and more client types. Below, we will detail the implementation settings on both data sets.

Setup with MNIST Data Set: In the empirical experiments on the MNIST data set, we follow the same setup as in our theoretical analysis, and study extreme scenarios without data distribution heterogeneity, i.e., client variance Ïƒ2=0superscriptğœ20\sigma^{2}=0. Specifically, we distribute data samples among 202020 clients in an i.i.d. fashion. Meanwhile, we adopt a convex multinomial logistic regression model, with initialized parameters ğ’˜0=ğŸsubscriptğ’˜00\boldsymbol{w}_{0}=\boldsymbol{0} and stochastic gradient descent (SGD) batch size b=32ğ‘32b=32. Similar to (Li etÂ al., 2020), we use an initial learning rate Î·0=0.001subscriptğœ‚00.001\eta_{0}=0.001 with decay rate Î·01+rsubscriptğœ‚01ğ‘Ÿ\frac{\eta_{0}}{1+r}, where rğ‘Ÿr is the communication round index, and the local iteration number E=20ğ¸20E=20. The total number of communication rounds during the training process is 500500500.

Setup with CIFAR-10 Data Set: In the empirical experiments on the CIFAR-101010 data set, we generalize from our theoretical setting to explore more complex and realistic non-convex models. Meanwhile, we simulate a more practical FL scenario of non-i.i.d. data distribution. In particular, we assign one class of data samples to type-111 clients, five classes to type-222 clients, and all 101010 classes to type-333 clients. We employ a convolutional neural network (CNN) model, which consists of two convolutional layers (Relu activation function), three fully connected layers, and a max pooling layer applied to each convolutional layer. We initialize the CNN model with parameters ğ’˜0=ğŸsubscriptğ’˜00\boldsymbol{w}_{0}=\boldsymbol{0} and set the SGD batch size to b=64ğ‘64b=64. The initial learning rate is Î·0=0.1subscriptğœ‚00.1\eta_{0}=0.1 with the decay rate Î·01+rsubscriptğœ‚01ğ‘Ÿ\frac{\eta_{0}}{1+r}, and the local iteration number E=30ğ¸30E=30. The total number of communication rounds during the training process is 600600600.

For all experiments on both data sets, we evaluate the aggregated FL model in each communication round, where without loss of generality, we take the test loss as the generalization error Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon of the trained FL model. Furthermore, to enhance reliability, our results are averaged over 30 experiments.

5.2. Social Efficiency of the SEMTS Mechanism and MTS Framework

Next, in Figure 5(b) and Figure 6(b), we evaluate the social efficiency of our proposed SEMTS mechanism and MTS framework, respectively.

5.2.1. Social Efficiency of SEMTS Mechanism

In Figure 5(b), we compare the social welfare of our proposed SEMTS mechanism against that of two following benchmarks under the MTS framework:

  • â€¢

    Dynamic Mechanism (Hu etÂ al., 2023): The dynamic mechanism proposed in (Hu etÂ al., 2023) considers clientsâ€™ evolving expectations of FL model performance, i.e., a network effects game. However, incomplete information and client heterogeneity could lead this benchmark to deviate from social welfare maximization.

  • â€¢

    Modified FL Mechanism (Yan and Ligeti, 2022): This benchmark is a modified version of the existing socially efficient mechanism in (Yan and Ligeti, 2022), in order to adapt to the MTS framework. Specifically, the modified FL mechanism sets the model price equal to the FL model utility but provides no participation reward, failing to deal with the network effects of client participation.

In the comparison of Figure 5(b), we illustrate how the social welfare of different mechanisms varies with the per-sample participation cost for all clients. From Figure 5(a) and 5(b), as the participation cost increases, the social welfare of all mechanisms declines and eventually reaches zero. However, our proposed SEMTS mechanism achieves significantly higher social welfare than the benchmarks. In particular, benchmarks can only achieve a relatively competitive social welfare to our SEMTS mechanism at low participation costs. Once costs increase further, the benchmarks suffer a quick drop in social welfare due to the client heterogeneity and negative network effects of client participation. In contrast, the SEMTS mechanism can incentivize heterogeneous clients to overcome the temporary phase of negative network effects or negative payoff, maximizing social welfare by exploiting positive network effects. Consequently, our mechanism maintains high social welfare even with high participation costs of clients.

5.2.2. Social Efficiency of MTS Framework

In Figure 6(b), we further present a comparison between the social welfare achieved by our proposed mechanism under the MTS framework versus two benchmarks under the FL framework:

  • â€¢

    Theoretical Optimum of FL Framework: This benchmark implies the highest possible performance of the existing FL frameworks (e.g., (McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Tan etÂ al., 2022; Abdulrahman etÂ al., 2021)) and thus effectively serves as a theoretical upper bound of social welfare for comparison.

  • â€¢

    Dynamic Mechanism (Hu etÂ al., 2023) of FL Framework: Although the dynamic mechanism (Hu etÂ al., 2023) under the FL framework can capture the dynamics of clientsâ€™ participation decisions to a certain degree, heterogeneous clients can only obtain and utilize the trained global FL model through participation, failing to maximize social welfare.

As shown in Figure 6(b), with the rise of the per-sample participation cost for clients, the social welfare declines under both frameworks. However, the MTS framework introduces an extra purchasing option and leverages network effects through our designed SEMTS mechanism. This significantly increases the social welfare and makes it more resilient to rising participation costs. As a result, except when the social welfare is zero under both frameworks, the MTS framework achieves an overall social welfare that is 148.86%percent148.86148.86\% and 300%percent300300\% higher than that of the theoretical optimum under the FL framework on the MNIST and CIFAR-101010 data set, respectively.

6. Conclusion

This work provides the first study on social welfare optimization in FL with network effects. Our analysis reveals that the network effects of client participation are not monotonic, which depends on client heterogeneity. To improve social welfare, we propose the MTS framework for FL. By exploiting network effects, our designed SEMTS mechanism under the MTS framework can incentivize heterogeneous clients to maximize social welfare, relying only on payments from model customers without extra incentive costs.

In future works, we will extend our incentive mechanism to consider clientsâ€™ strategic decisions of data contribution, such as limited participation using only part of their private data. Additionally, we will refine our theoretical model by exploring clientsâ€™ utility and computational heterogeneity. Such advancements, while significantly complicating the equilibrium analysis and mechanism design, are expected to enhance the practicality of our research.
